metadata.name: Kyma #53
metadata.description:
Kyma (/kee-ma/, κύμα) is a Greek word meaning wave. It is my exploration of an acoustic phenomenon known as ‘Chladni Patterns’. 

Ernst Florens Friedrich Chladni was a German physicist and musician. He was a pioneer of modern acoustics and made numerous contributions to the field. Chladni's work had a significant influence on the development of modern music theory and the technology of musical instruments. In 1787, Chladni was trying to understand how sound waves propagate and interact with objects. By vibrating a metal plate and sprinkling sand on it, he observed that the sand arranged itself into distinct patterns. These patterns are created due to the interaction between the sound waves and the plate: the sound waves cause the plate to vibrate, which in turn causes the sand to move. The sand will move away from areas of high vibration and towards areas of low vibration. This creates a unique pattern of ridges, circles, and many other shapes.

Kyma continues this study by adding color, light, and composition to the equation. Each iteration is a unique combination of two Chladni plates with different characteristics, accompanied by a palette, background lighting, and variational drawing algorithm. Plates interact with each other, forming patterns from the small detailed net-like grid to megalithic sculptures of unknown creatures and windows to another worlds.

Please use fullscreen or download artwork in high resolution for a better viewing experience.

Rendering can be computationally heavy, please be patient and give it some time to draw.
Chrome is highly recommended for live mode and high res saving.

Made with love, math, and p5js. 

Controls in fullscreen:
[1] - save PNG 2400 x 1600
[2] - save PNG 4800 x 3200
[3] - save PNG 9600 x 6400
[4] - save PNG 14400 x 9600

metadata.name: Trust #305
metadata.description:
Trust is an abstraction of the creative process, finding the line just before form becomes texture. Your experience with the painting requires trust; trust that something will appear from the chaos of the empty space, trust that the composition you imagine halfway through will evolve along with your ideas, and trust that the etchings lend a helping hand to the message of the piece. You may find yourself pulled left and right when decisions are made, and your interpretation at 25%, 50%, and 90% will all differ. This is what makes creating so fulfilling to me, a work of art can change course wildly from start to finish, ever molding itself until it enters the kiln.

Press ‘1’, ‘2’, or  ‘3’ to increase resolution (default is 1, higher than default may not work on certain browsers. Successfully testing in Chrome, Brave, and Opera GX with hardware acceleration enabled)

Click or tap to zoom to full res (exact zoom depends on your display)
Press ’s’ to save a .png
Press ’t’ to toggle brush texture

Created with p5.js and chroma.js

metadata.name: Digital Expression #6
metadata.description:
Digital Expression is a work of art that brings the power of simple geometric shapes, lines mix and reveal the power to generate complex, interesting and unexpected formations. All this visual versatility comes to life and a true Digital Expression that dialogues with everyone who views it.

Create with p5.js and p5.grain.

- Press "S" in live view mode after loading to save at 2000x2000px.
license:

CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: Artifice #303
metadata.description:
This series is is about playful obfuscation.

The fxtext article linked on the main profect goes more in-depth into what is meant by that, as well as the events that led to this collection.

5640 bytes of Vanilla JS with no libraries. Palettes make up a third of the code.

In live mode:
‘S’ : save as png (3000 × 3600)
’V’ : save as svg (without grain)

URL params in live mode:
‘g=n’ : no grain
‘g=p’ : paper grain
‘h=t’ : high resolution mode, 9000 ×10600 (Chrome only, and may take a moment)

For example, if you wanted paper grain in high resolution, append “&g=p&h=t” to the url in live mode.

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save a png with those settings applied.

metadata.name: Gentrax EP #41
metadata.description:
Gentrax EP is a generative audiovisual artwork. Each iteration produces a generative house/garage track ~3 minutes in length while drawing out accompanying artwork. Live piece is aspect ratio agnostic and scales to any window size, but an aspect of 1:1.414 is preferred and can be set with an URL parameter.

Audio controls:
1-7: Channel mutes/unmutes
a: Filter up 
z: Filter down
c: Flanger on/off
v: Reverb (cycle thru three settings)
q: Switch bassline octave&seq (cycle thru three settings)
b: Portamento on/off

Visual controls: 
p: Fast forward to final artwork
o: Save canvas

Url parameters: 
&w=800 : Set width of canvas. If aspect ratio is not defined, artwork will be in preferred aspect ratio (1.41414)
&a=1.5 : Set aspect ratio. number <1 = Wide canvas
&wl=1 : Locks canvas aspect ratio to preferred 


made with p5.js & tone.js
Using tonejs synthesis for bass plus oneshot samples from various drum machines & Alpha Juno 2
<3

CC-BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: The Fringe #239
metadata.description:
We are innately aware of our bodies' position through perception of space. If we are visibly surrounded by walls with flooring under, a ceiling above, and a window facing the sky, we know we are inside of an enclosed space, with a view of outside. But how does a room stopped being an enclosed space? Can a space with 3 walls be considered a room? If we are surrounded by walls but our ceiling is gone, then are we inside or outside? This is an exploration on the edges of our ability to perceive space. The fringes that instill some fear in our mind. And that fear is failing to make sense of our position in a space that slowly loses its tangibility.

------------
Press [s] to save captured image
------------
It may take a few seconds to render, depending on the device.

created using WEBGL on p5.js
dirbots - Jan23

metadata.name: LOOP #37
metadata.description:
Everything we think as a reality is just a dream.

The truth is something else and you are not aware of it when you are in the loop.
 
Kill the fear !
Break the frame &
See the light :)

metadata.name: Hexagones Landscape #285
metadata.description:
An undulating (sometimes) landscape made up of hexagons (or "Hexagones" laying in wait) to celebrate the first birthday of fxhash. Written at the last minute the weekend before the birthday week.

A simpler 16 colour version of this project was originally coded on an Atari ST 512, about 32 years ago, figured it was time to update it.

INSTRUCTIONS ::

h - Toggle high-res
s - Download and save image

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS ::

High-res will output a 6,553 x 8,192 image, at 300dpi it should print at...

21.84 x 27.3 inches
55.47 x 69.3 cm
